storyContent.tagHTML: An eight-year-old prince named Aimuttä was playing when he saw Gautam-swämi, the chief disciple of Bhagawän Mahävir, going for alms. Delighted, the young prince invited the monk to his palace. Aimuttä happily offered his favorite food, ladoos (sweets), to Gautam-swämi.

When the monk prepared to leave, Aimuttä offered to carry his heavy bag. Gautam-swämi explained that only those who had taken Dikshä (vows of renunciation) could carry it. This sparked the young prince's curiosity, and he asked to learn about the life of a monk. After Gautam-swämi explained how monks avoid sinful activities, Aimuttä declared, “In that case, Gurudev, I want to take Dikshä.”
Bälmuni (young monk) Aimuttä.
An Innocent Mistake and Sincere Repentance

One day, the young monk saw children playing with paper boats in a puddle. Forgetting his vows, he excitedly joined them, using the lid of his container as a boat. Other monks gently reminded him that playing in water causes harm to living beings and violates his vows. Bälmuni Aimuttä was instantly filled with deep remorse.

Iriyävahiyam Sutra (a prayer for forgiveness), he came to the part about harming water beings. The memory of his childhood mistake flooded back, and his repentance was so profound and sincere that he destroyed all of his destructive karmas on the spot and attained Keval-jnän (omniscience). Bhagawän Mahävir himself confirmed this to the other monks, teaching them that there is no age barrier to enlightenment. Bälmuni Aimuttä eventually attained liberation.

events.title: Meeting Gautam-swämi
events.description: The eight-year-old Prince Aimuttä sees Gautam-swämi and invites him to the palace for alms.

events.title: A Desire for Dikshä
events.description: After learning about the life of a monk, Aimuttä declares his own desire to take Dikshä.

events.title: A Wise Argument
events.description: He wisely convinces his mother to give her permission for his renunciation.

events.title: Bälmuni Aimuttä
events.description: At age eight, Prince Aimuttä takes Dikshä and becomes a young monk (Bälmuni).

events.title: An Innocent Mistake
events.description: One day, he forgets his vows and joins some children in playing with boats in a water puddle.

events.title: Immediate Remorse
events.description: When reminded by other monks that this harms living beings, he feels instant and deep regret.

events.title: Reciting a Sutra
events.description: While reciting the Iriyävahiyam Sutra, he remembers his childhood sin of playing in the water.

events.title: Profound Repentance
events.description: His repentance for the act is so sincere and overwhelming that it purifies his soul completely.

events.title: Attaining Keval-jnän
events.description: In that moment of pure repentance, he destroys his karmas and attains omniscience, becoming a Kevali.

charactersData.name: Aimuttä Muni
charactersData.description: A prince who took Dikshä at the tender age of eight. His story highlights that there is no age barrier to spiritual pursuit and that sincere repentance for even small, unintentional mistakes can lead to liberation.

charactersData.name: Gautam-swämi
charactersData.description: The chief disciple of Bhagawän Mahävir, whose brief explanation of a monk's life was enough to inspire the young prince to renounce the world.

charactersData.name: Queen Shrimati
charactersData.description: Aimuttä's mother. Although she loved her son, she was wise enough to recognize his spiritual potential and grant him permission to become a monk.

charactersData.name: Bhagawän Mahävir
charactersData.description: The 24th Tirthankar, who confirmed Aimuttä Muni's attainment of Keval-jnän to the other monks, teaching them a valuable lesson.

quizData.question: What was the name of the eight-year-old prince?
Who was the chief disciple of Mahävir that Aimuttä met?
What did Aimuttä offer Gautam-swämi as alms?
What did Gautam-swämi say was required to carry his alms bag?
quizData.answer: One had to have taken Dikshä and become a monk.

quizData.question: What was the main condition Bhagawän Mahävir set for Aimuttä to take Dikshä?
quizData.answer: He had to get his parents’ permission.

quizData.question: What was Aimuttä's argument to his mother about why he shouldn't wait to take Dikshä?
quizData.answer: He said no one knows what will happen tomorrow or who will die first, so he shouldn't miss the opportunity.

quizData.question: What did Aimuttä do that violated his monastic vows?
quizData.answer: He played with a container lid as a boat in a water puddle.

quizData.question: Why was playing in the water considered a violation of his vows?
quizData.answer: Because it causes harm to the many living beings that live in the water.

quizData.question: Years later, what was Aimuttä Muni reciting when he remembered this mistake?
What happened as a result of his sincere and profound repentance?
quizData.answer: He destroyed all of his destructive karma and attained omniscience (Keval-jnän).

quizData.question: When senior monks told Aimuttä he was sitting in the wrong place (for Kevalis), who corrected them?
What is the main moral of this story?
quizData.answer: That there is no age limit for spiritual pursuit and that sincere repentance can eliminate bad karma.

graphicsData.title: An Offering of Sweets
graphicsData.description: The young Prince Aimuttä joyfully offers his favorite food, ladoos, as alms to Gautam-swämi, the chief disciple of Mahävir.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young boy in princely clothes happily giving sweets to a monk.

graphicsData.title: A Child's Wisdom
graphicsData.description: Aimuttä wisely convinces his mother to let him become a monk, arguing that no one knows what tomorrow holds and he must seize the opportunity now.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young boy speaking earnestly to his mother, the queen, who looks surprised and impressed.

graphicsData.title: An Innocent Transgression
graphicsData.description: Forgetting his vows for a moment, the young monk Aimuttä playfully sails the lid of his container like a boat in a water puddle.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A young monk crouching by a puddle, playing with a small object in the water.

graphicsData.title: A Gentle Reminder
graphicsData.description: Other, older monks see him playing and gently remind him that as a monk, he has taken a vow not to harm any living beings, including those in the water.
graphicsData.imageAlt: An older monk speaking kindly to the young monk, who looks up with a dawning realization.

graphicsData.title: Repentance and Realization
graphicsData.description: Years later, while reciting a prayer for forgiveness, the memory of his mistake returns, and Aimuttä Muni is filled with such profound and sincere repentance.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk in deep meditation with tears in his eyes, feeling immense remorse.

graphicsData.title: Enlightenment Through Forgiveness
graphicsData.description: This act of pure repentance is so powerful that it destroys all his remaining karmas, and he attains omniscience (Keval-jnän) on the spot.
graphicsData.imageAlt: A monk glowing with a brilliant white light, having achieved the highest state of knowledge.
